1096875667403137024.text: Related rant: registry locking is one of the stupidest things in all of internet security. Model is lock/unlock your domain on demand. But if attackers have the EPP credentials they can just keep trying changes until you happen to unlock!

1096874979050762241.text: DNSSEC actually makes this worse: hijack the domain at the registrar, change the ZSK, then sign some very high TTL records. Create new zone cuts for the common names, like www. and poison with high-TTL DS records, get them into the common caches, then throw away the DNSKEY.

1116480143726403584.text: Sturgeon’s Amnesia: forgetting that 90% of everything is crap, and that the subtext of that rule is not that we give up on everything.

1116480062667272192.text: Inverse “Gall-Mann” Amnesia: assuming the position that journalism is fundamentally and intrinsically untrustworthy, generated as it is by “non-experts”, while forgetting that John Carreyrou, a non-expert biz reporter, almost single-handedly brought down Theranois.

1116480005230477312.text: Djikstra Amnesia: working in technology while making, as all humans do, all manner of errors and omissions, many quite harmful, and forgetting about all of them while holding other professions to impossible standards.

1116479960187834368.text: Michael Crichton’s “Gell-Mann” Amnesia: reading a sci/tech story in the news, spotting obvious errors, then forgetting about those errors, and how untrustworthy the news is, by the next story.

1113876260504199168.text:
I will conclude by repeating an observation I already made:

Most CS grads go on to a fruitful career in wiring databases to HTML tags. And yet the field has _less than 20%_ women participation. 

But women have spent the last 40+ years killing it in cryptography.

1113875843229593600.text: And that Edna Grossman co-designed DES, which you may have heard of. #womencryptographers

1113875554921529344.text: But I will point out what was pointed out to me an hour ago, which is that the first president of the IACR was Dorothy Denning. #womencryptographers

1113875333332258817.text: could i go on and on and on here? yes i could! i have (checks notes) more than 50 more names in this list, but i’ll stop shortly because the pretense that i am tuned in enough to know all these people myself is already bugging me

1113874932079919107.text: Joanne Woodage at Royal Halloway published on backdoors in CSPRNGs, which is how the cool SIGINT agencies actually backdoor cryptosystems. #womencryptographers

1113874291987222529.text: Kaisa Nyburg invented Nyburg S-boxes, a refinement of the nonlinear core of modern block ciphers, which features in Rijndael, perhaps better known to you as AES. #womencryptographers

1113873540493795328.text: Emilia Käsper was a DROWN-attack researcher, co-designed Certificate Transparency, and published attacks on GCM. #womencryptographers

1113872397545951232.text: Helena Handschuh is a technical director at Cryptography Research and Rambus, the industry’s foremost modernizers of side-channel attacks. She’s published attacks on RC5, SEAL, eSTREAM ciphers, RC6, and a variety of tamper-proof devices. #womencryptographers

1113872284199071754.text: if you’re an offensive security person and you know who Mark Dowd is, you should know who Nadia Henninger is, just as way of having pride in your own damn profession.

1113872129592893447.text: Here’s a name even I’m smart enough to rattle off the top of my head: Nadia Henninger, among the best-known practical offensive cryptography researchers — Dual EC, DROWN, cold-boot attacks, Coppersmithing smartcards. #womencryptographers

1113871763782369280.text: Lenore Blum, “one of the Blums” from the Blum Blum Shub CSRNG. Founded Women@SCS at CMU, where she was a distinguished professor: https://www.women.cs.cmu.edu/  Hell yes, Lenore Blum. #womencryptographers

1113871513042792453.text: because i am dumb i am going to give a lot of people short shrift in my little capsule twitter summaries, and i would be grateful for anyone who trues any of them up!

1113871321799254022.text: Tal Rabin heads IBM’s crypto research group and advanced the art of signature algorithms and, in particular, multiparty secret sharing. #womencryptographers

1113871130467631104.text: but since crypto is _LESS_ male-dominated than “ordinary” CS, and yet _FAR MORE_ demanding than the sort of “plug this database column into this form field” work CS grads end up doing, women excelling in crypto is a valuable corrective to bias against women in tech.

1113870546662494208.text: an aside: cryptography has more women practitioners than many (most?) CS fields; it’s one of the first things you’ll notice at an academic crypto conference. but the field is still male-dominated, which is a travesty.

1113870295524417538.text: Wang Xiaoyun broke MD5 and SHA1. #womencryptographers

1113870144839745536.text: If you follow crypto nerds on Twitter you’re also surely thinking about Tanja Lange, crypto chair at Eindhoven and bad-ass elliptic curve and PQ researcher. We got tips for cryptopals from Tanja. #womencryptographers

1113869700478509056.text: The obvious place to start would be Shafi Goldwasser, a giant in the field, Turing award winner, co-inventor of zero-knowledge proofs. #womencryptographers

Avoiding DNSSEC is literally the “primary motivation” behind MTA-STS (sponsors: Google, Yahoo, Comcast, Microsoft); it’s right there at the start of the RFC. Paul is going full Baghdad Bob on this stuff. I love him so much. 

https://twitter.com/letoams/status/1099803716708904960 …pic.twitter.com/d25HI1irtJ

1099800192088444931.text: I used to worry DNSSEC would actually happen, and we’d all have key escrow, just implemented insidiously through the USG’s DNS security push. That’s why I kept writing about it! Now, not so much worried anymore; I just want to try to predict exactly when it’ll finally end.

1099799865322815488.text: The two major practical problems DNSSEC was meant to still solve in 2018 — CA misissuance and SMTP downgrade attacks — are being addressed w/o DNSSEC. And DoH is obviously going to secure more DNS lookups than DNSSEC has in its whole lifetime, despite being brand new.

1099799212919803906.text: This isn’t snark! It’s a real phenomenon. Against stagnant deployment numbers, most of them security theater from registrars opting all users in, we’re seeing the rise of DoH, MTA-STS, RDAP, and CT.

1080612767080562688.text: To do that, exploit inter-procedural analysis: smuggle the -0 through a value the compiler can’t keep track of statically. Constant folding isn’t a real security barrier, can simply be turned off by the right code. (Here: apparently just stick -0 in a JS object).

1080611806979280896.text:
But in reality: tricksier! The v8 JIT is smart, will see an expression that seems to constantly evaluate to 0, and replace the computation with the constant. 

Need to bypass constant folding to let the malicious computation survive.

1080610860891103239.text:
Define an array of some fixed size. Then index the array with http://Object.is (Math.expm(-0),-0) * INDEX. 

Analyzer assumes: must be zero, no check needed.

At runtime: isn’t zero, is INDEX, check was definitely needed. Boom.

1080610501623717888.text:
That sounds innocuous and in isolation is.

But the v8 JIT uses type information for static analysis, which guides the rest of compilation. 

So: a = http://Object.is (Math.expm(-0), -0) is assumed false by static analysis. But isn’t! The analyzer is wrong.

1080609976706613254.text:
Underlying bug: 

Math.expm1 computes (e^x)-1. v8 JIT assumes this will produce either a normal float or NaN.

But expm(-0) produces float -0, a case the JIT misses.
